image.altText: A crowd of people stand on the street outside an Optus store

items.synopsis: Optus says it "may take a few hours for all services to recover", with the telco yet to identify the root issue behind today's huge outage. Follow live.

title.children: Optus announces some services are being restored, but warns it may take a few hours

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Service has not been fully restored.  Optus NBN is still down! - Ben. While Optus's CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin has said that the telco's services are now fully restored, there may still be a delay before that change takes effect on your personal device. "The way that we restored services meant that we had to bring services online on a progressive basis so that has been rolling out throughout the day," Rosmarin said. About half an hour ago, Optus told customers on its website that it was "continuing" to restore connectivity. It said the service should restore automatically, though some customers may need to restart their device or turn airplane mode on and off again.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why am I still not getting service?

children.content: Service has not been fully restored.  Optus NBN is still down!
- Ben
While Optus's CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin has said that the telco's services are now fully restored, there may still be a delay before that change takes effect on your personal device.
"The way that we restored services meant that we had to bring services online on a progressive basis so that has been rolling out throughout the day," Rosmarin said.
About half an hour ago, Optus told customers on its website that it was "continuing" to restore connectivity.
It said the service should restore automatically, though some customers may need to restart their device or turn airplane mode on and off again.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Optus has just posted a new update on its website. It says internet and phone services "are continuing to be restored". "Service will be automatically restored," the statement says. "Some customers may need to restart their device or turn airplane mode on then off." Here's the rest of the statement:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Services are continuing to be restored,' Optus says

children.content: Optus has just posted a new update on its website.
It says internet and phone services "are continuing to be restored".
"Service will be automatically restored," the statement says.
"Some customers may need to restart their device or turn airplane mode on then off."
Here's the rest of the statement:
(Supplied)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin has repeated her apologies for the outage but says the company cannot provide further detail about the outage until it conducts a thorough investigation. "In my three and a half years, as the CEO of Optus, we've never had an outage of this nature," she said. "So it's a very rare occurrence, but unfortunately, it does happen. It happens to telcos all around the world. It happens to other telcos in Australia. "We try and avoid it happening and we will make sure we learn as much as we possibly can from what occurred and hopefully keep it as an extremely rare occurrence." You can read more about what she said here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Optus CEO says the outage was 'a very rare occurrence'

featuredLink.title: Optus blames 'technical network fault' for outage but needs further investigation to determine root cause

children.content: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin has repeated her apologies for the outage but says the company cannot provide further detail about the outage until it conducts a thorough investigation.
"In my three and a half years, as the CEO of Optus, we've never had an outage of this nature," she said.
"So it's a very rare occurrence, but unfortunately, it does happen. It happens to telcos all around the world. It happens to other telcos in Australia.
"We try and avoid it happening and we will make sure we learn as much as we possibly can from what occurred and hopefully keep it as an extremely rare occurrence."
You can read more about what she said here:

items.synopsis: The South Australian premier describes the Optus outage as the single biggest telecommunications outage seen in Australia and says he believes most governments are affected in some form.

title.children: Mental health triage services impacted in South Australia by Optus outage

image.altText: A swing with a blue rope tied to it with a blurred house in the background

items.synopsis: More than 100,000 online and telephone reports were made to SA's child abuse line last financial year, a 9 per cent increase from the year prior.

title.children: SA faces ‘public health emergency’ due to rise in suspected child neglect, minister warns

image.altText: A labrador assistance dog looks at meerkat behind a glass barrier while its handler holds on to its leash

items.synopsis: Assistance dogs and their handlers are welcome at the Adelaide Zoo for the first time following walking tests to record the reactions of dogs and zoo residents.

title.children: Assistance dogs welcomed at Adelaide Zoo under first-of-its-kind accessibility program

image.altText: Woman in pyjamas sits on edge of bed and grips stomach

items.synopsis: Rotavirus cases in South Australia have more than doubled since the same time last year, SA Health figures show, as a number of childcare centres have been impacted with gastro-related illness.

title.children: Multiple gastro outbreaks across SA as data reveals rotavirus cases doubled in past year

image.altText: Two women smiling while one cuts a red ribbon.

items.synopsis: According to the South Australian government, women aged 55 and over are one of the fastest growing populations who experience homelessness.

title.children: 'I can feel like a human again': Hopes new SA housing trial will divert women from homelessness

image.altText: A group of customers surround a retail worker inside of a shop

items.synopsis: Optus says it is working to solve the issue impacting mobile and internet customers, with services down since early this morning across the country.

title.children: 'No indication' cyber attack behind Optus outage, CEO says

image.altText: A close up shot of crocodile teeth, with brown stains on them

items.synopsis: Northern Territory cattle producer Colin Deveraux knows he is lucky to be alive after being attacked by a 3.2-metre saltwater crocodile.

title.children: 'He shook me like a rag doll': Cattleman survives croc attack by biting back

image.altText: Composite image of two young men, with police behind them.

items.synopsis: A man who lit bushfires and filmed videos pledging his loyalty to Islamic State is found guilty of terrorism-related offences, but his older brother will walk free after being cleared by a jury.

title.children: Man who pledged loyalty to IS and lit fires on Melbourne's outskirts is found guilty of terror offences

image.altText: The crumpled front of a white BMW SUV, surrounded by emergency services tape.

items.synopsis: Police have interviewed the driver at the centre of a tragic crash that killed five people in the regional Victorian town of Daylesford, but no charges have been laid.

title.children: Lawyer for Daylesford crash driver says ‘family man’ is deeply distressed and remains in hospital care

image.altText: An inflatable pool with a blow up ring floating in it

items.synopsis: A Perth woman who held the heads of both her young children underwater in an inflatable pool is jailed, and banned from ever contacting them again.

title.children: Perth mother jailed after holding children's heads underwater in blow-up pool

image.altText: A sign saying "caution" in front of an open pit coal mine and power station.

items.synopsis: The gap between climate rhetoric and fossil fuel use is growing, according to a UN report that warns the world's carbon budget has almost been used up.

title.children: Climate disconnect grows wider as fossil fuel use soars to 'double' required level by 2030

image.altText: A close-up photograph of a burgundy-coloured flying duck orchid

items.synopsis: An amateur photographer has been looking across two states for almost a decade for a small orchid resembling a flying duck. Then a tip from a friend finally ended his long search.

title.children: Nine-year 'duck' hunt ends as photographer snaps elusive orchid

image.altText: A painted mural of a smiling woman wearing a headscarf and jewellery piece, a man and a child in turbans.

items.synopsis: Sunny Singh was the target of a racially charged video when running for local council five years ago. A colourful mural celebrating Indian culture and since been unveiled in his regional community, prompting praise from the Sikh councillor.

title.children: Port Augusta unveils mural in celebration of Indian cultures five years after racist video targets Sikh councillor

image.altText: Gary Clough stands in front of a brick archway with a sign that reads Garden of Remembrance Port Lincoln RSL.

items.synopsis: When state government funding for the upkeep of South Australia's only RSL cemetery ran out earlier this year, Port Lincoln's sub-branch took matters into its own hands.

title.children: RSL crowdfunding to keep veterans' cemetery afloat after grant money dries up

image.altText: A composite picture of Glenn Maxwell

items.synopsis: Glenn Maxwell's stunning match-winning double century at the Cricket World Cup has been hailed as the greatest ODI innings of all time. Here are the performances he's up against for that title.

title.children: Glenn Maxwell's innings is 'without a doubt' the best of all time — these are the performances it beats

image.altText: A woman uses her phone outside an Optus store as a man looks at his.

items.synopsis: Services are being restored after millions of Optus customers were left without phone and internet services. Here's what we know about the outage.

title.children: What caused the Optus outage, and how long was it down for? Here's what we know

image.altText: Palestinian family reacts following Israeli airstrike

items.synopsis: At least 500 more people, most of them foreign nationals, cross into Egypt after the Rafah border crossing re-opens, while an Israeli government spokesperson tells the ABC the country will have to exercise "ultimate security control" over the Gaza Strip. Follow live.

title.children: DFAT confirms three Australians among new Rafah crossing evacuations, Israel wants 'ultimate security control' over Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An Israeli spokesman claims more than 9,000 rockets have been fired at Israel since October 7. Lieutenant Colonel Jonathan Conricus says "most of them" were intercepted by the Iron Dome, during a briefing on social media platform X. Speaking about Israel's military operation in northern Gaza, Lt. Col Conricus says forces will continue"going stronghold after stronghold". He says this includes Jabalia and Shati refugee camps.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More than 9,000 rockets fired at Israel so far: IDF spokesman

children.content: An Israeli spokesman claims more than 9,000 rockets have been fired at Israel since October 7.
Lieutenant Colonel Jonathan Conricus says "most of them" were intercepted by the Iron Dome, during a briefing on social media platform X.
Speaking about Israel's military operation in northern Gaza, Lt. Col Conricus says forces will continue"going stronghold after stronghold".
He says this includes Jabalia and Shati refugee camps.

props.alt: Man wearing army uniform stands in frnt of Israeli flag

children.content: Israeli spokesman Jonathan Conricus provides a military briefing.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US House has voted to censure Democrat Rashida Tlaib, the congress's lone Palestinian American representative, for comments she made regarding the Israel-Gaza war. Twenty-two Democrats joined with most Republicans in the chamber to censure Ms Tlaib for allegedly "promoting false narratives" on Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel and "calling for the destruction of the state of Israel". The final vote tally in the Republican-controlled chamber was 234-188 in favor of censure. The symbolic rebuke has no specific punishment. Ms Tlaib has repeatedly condemned the Hamas assault, while also criticizing US support for Israel as civilian deaths in Gaza continue to rise. The measure specifically cited a video Ms Tlaib published on social media containing the phrase "from the river to the sea". The pro-Palestinian rallying cry is viewed by many Jews as anti-Semitic and calling for Israel's eradication. She also enraged many fellow Democrats when she posted a video accusing President Joe Biden of supporting "the genocide of the Palestinian people". Israel denies accusations of genocide. Ms Tlaib rejected accusations of anti-Semitism during a speech on the House floor. "I am the only Palestinian-American in Congress, and my perspective is needed more than ever," Ms Tlaib says. "My criticism has always been of the Israeli government and [Prime Minister Benjamin] Netanyahu's actions … The idea that criticising the government of Israel is anti-Semitic sets a very dangerous precedent. "Palestinian people are not disposable", Ms Tlaib added, taking a long pause as she became overcome with emotion.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'My perspective is needed more than ever': US House censures lone Palestinian-American politician over comments

children.content: The US House has voted to censure Democrat
Rashida Tlaib
, the congress's lone Palestinian American representative, for comments she made regarding the Israel-Gaza war.

props.alt: Rashida Tlaib speaks at a hearing at the US house of congress.

children.content: US Representative Rashida Tlaib.
(Reuters: Sarah Silbiger)
Twenty-two Democrats joined with most Republicans in the chamber to censure Ms Tlaib for allegedly "promoting false narratives" on Hamas's
October 7 attack on Israel and "calling for the destruction of the state of Israel".
The final vote tally in the Republican-controlled chamber was 234-188 in favor of censure.
The symbolic rebuke has no specific punishment.
Ms Tlaib has repeatedly condemned the Hamas assault, while also criticizing US support for Israel as civilian deaths in Gaza continue to rise.
The measure specifically cited a video Ms Tlaib published on social media containing the phrase "from the river to the sea".
The pro-Palestinian rallying cry is viewed by many Jews as anti-Semitic and calling for Israel's eradication.
She also enraged many fellow Democrats when she posted a video accusing President Joe Biden of supporting "the genocide of the Palestinian people".
Israel denies accusations of genocide.
Ms Tlaib rejected accusations of anti-Semitism during a speech on the House floor.
"I am the only Palestinian-American in Congress, and my perspective is needed more than ever," Ms Tlaib says.

"My criticism has always been of the Israeli government and [Prime Minister Benjamin] Netanyahu's actions … The idea that criticising the government of Israel is anti-Semitic sets a very dangerous precedent.
"Palestinian people are not disposable", Ms Tlaib added, taking a long pause as she became overcome with emotion.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier today we reported that three more Australians have been evacuated from Gaza to Egypt via the Rafah crossing, bringing the total of evacuated Australians to 28. The evacuation of a family of three Australians took place overnight, Foreign Minister Penny Wong confirmed in a post on X. "An Australian family of three has been able to leave Gaza via the Rafah crossing overnight", Foreign Minister Penny Wong said. "They are being supported by our consular staff in Egypt." DFAT continues to assist 76 people remaining in Gaza, she said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian family of three evacuated from Gaza overnight, DFAT continues to assist 76 people, Wong says

children.content: Earlier today we reported that
three more Australians have been evacuated from Gaza
to Egypt via the Rafah crossing, bringing the total of evacuated Australians to 28.
The evacuation of a family of three Australians took place overnight, Foreign Minister Penny Wong confirmed in a post on X.
"An Australian family of three has been able to leave Gaza via the Rafah crossing overnight", Foreign Minister Penny Wong said.
"They are being supported by our consular staff in Egypt."
DFAT continues to assist 76 people remaining in Gaza, she said.

image.altText: birds eye view shot of several buildings reduced to grey rubble

items.synopsis: The United Nations Relief and Works Agency (URNWA) says there eight refugee camps in the Gaza Strip, according to the Gaza's health ministry, five have been hit.

title.children: There are eight refugee camps in Gaza — five have reportedly been struck since war with Israel began

image.altText: Muslim woman wearing a white hijab, red shirt and black jacket, sitting in her home.

items.synopsis: Hanaa Elmobayed was one of 19 Australians who made it out of Gaza through the Rafah crossing with Egypt last weekend. But there were many times the mother of five feared she'd never make it back to her family.

title.children: Hanaa was visiting her mum in Gaza when the war broke out. Now home, she's scarred from what she saw

image.altText: Kathleen Folbigg releases first public statement after release

items.synopsis: Kathleen Folbigg was released from prison in June after being pardoned over the deaths of her four children. A final report after an inquiry into her convictions was released on Wednesday.

title.children: Kathleen Folbigg case referred for possible appeal after final conviction report released

image.altText: Boris Johnson grimaces while sitting behind a Union Jack flag

items.synopsis: The former UK prime minister's senior advisor says Mr Johnson hoped to show the public COVID-19 did not pose a threat in the early days of the nation's outbreak.

title.children: Former aide says Boris Johnson wanted to be injected with COVID-19 on live TV

image.altText: Front on view of an icebreaker ship.

items.synopsis: Officials at the Australian Antarctic Division were left scrambling after a decision to block RSV Nuyina from transiting the Tasman Bridge and refuelling close to port, with the true cost of a 660km detour now revealed.

title.children: What should have been a 4km refuelling trip for Australia's icebreaker is now a 660km debacle

image.altText: Front of a car crashed into a tree

items.synopsis: Alleged driver Nicholas Thew to remain behind bars after being charged with a number of offences over a crash in Sydney's south-west that resulted in the deaths of two teenage passengers.

title.children: 'Underlying issues' involved in Sydney car crash that killed two boys, court hears

image.altText: A horse-like head emerges in gas and dust from a region of space 1,375 light-years from Earth

items.synopsis: The European Space Agency wows with the first full colour images from the Euclid space telescope, a "dark matter detective" with the specs to rival the famed James Webb.

title.children: Move over, JWST: First Euclid telescope images of the cosmos stun

image.altText: Large plumes of black smoke erupt behind a fenced off military base

items.synopsis: Firefighting services across WA are being stretched to the limit with dozens of blazes burning already, in a bushfire season the emergency services commissioner says is up to eight weeks ahead of schedule.

title.children: 'A hell of a lot' of fires: WA’s bushfire season arrives up to two months early

image.altText: An older woman, Eileen Kramer, wears a ballgown while sitting in a wheelchair

items.synopsis: Louis Armstrong was nice, and Ella Fitzgerald was not so nice, according to 109-year-old Eileen Kramer who is not planning on hanging up her dancing shoes.

title.children: Draped in white feathers and wearing a pair of sparkly ballet flats, Eileen celebrated her 109th birthday in style

image.altText: police tape

items.synopsis: A jury has heard a planned street fight on the NSW Central Coast lasted less than three seconds before a 13-year-old boy fatally stabbed another 13-year-old boy.

title.children: Teenager stabbed boy, 13, to death with kitchen knife during street fight, court hears

image.altText: Donna Simpson, Josh Cunningham and Vikki Thorn sitting on seats in back garden

items.synopsis: Some fans of an Aussie folk rock band will have to wait a little longer to see them in concert as vocalist Donna Simpson recovers from an e-scooter crash.

title.children: The Waifs push back concert after singer suffers collapsed lung in e-scooter fall

image.altText: Abattoirs feeling the pinch

items.synopsis: Meat inspectors and vets are walking off the job today, with the industry saying the strike action will create backlogs that affect domestic and export sectors.

title.children: Abattoir inspectors and vets strike for 'decent pay' as meat industry slams 'unions gone wild'

image.altText: An artsy night picture of the sign at Casuarina Prison

items.synopsis: The ABC can reveal more details about the conduct of a senior officer on duty the night 16-year-old Cleveland Dodd was found unresponsive in his cell at Unit 18. Warning: This story discusses incidents of self-harm and contains the images of an Indigenous person who has died.

title.children: Senior officer alerted over Cleveland Dodd was lying down partially undressed in his dark office

image.altText: Donald Trump is drawn gesturing with his hands on the stand.

items.synopsis: "This is a very unfair trial, and I hope the public is watching," Donald Trump told a frustrated judge yesterday. They were telling words, giving an insight into a courtroom strategy few defendants would dare to employ.

title.children: Insulting a judge might seem like a strange strategy, but Trump had a bigger courtroom plan
